content: The Act titled "American 5-Cent Coin Design Continuity Act of 2003" establishes the designs on the 5-cent coin. The Act allows the Secretary of the Treasury to change the design of the 5-cent coin for 2003-2005 to commemorate the bicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase and Lewis and Clark expedition, depicting President Thomas Jefferson on the obverse. The Secretary of the Treasury can change the reverse design of the 5-cent coins issued during 2003-2005 to depict images related to the Louisiana Purchase or the expedition of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark. The coins must still meet all other requirements for inscriptions and designations. SEC. 102 amends the design of the 5-cent coin to feature Thomas Jefferson on the obverse and Monticello on the reverse. SEC. 103 establishes the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 103 establishes the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee under Section 5135 of title 31, United States Code. The Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee (Advisory Committee) is established to advise the Secretary of the Treasury on coin themes and designs. It consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including individuals with specific qualifications. The Committee is under the oversight of the Secretary. The Advisory Committee consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, with specific qualifications in numismatics, American history, medallic arts or sculpture, and curating numismatic collections. The Advisory Committee consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, with specific qualifications in numismatics, American history, medallic arts or sculpture, and curating numismatic collections. The committee includes individuals representing the general public's interests in US coinage, as well as four persons appointed based on recommendations from key officials in the House and Senate. The Advisory Committee members are appointed for 4-year terms, with initial appointees serving varying term lengths. No individual can be appointed while working for the Federal Government. The Advisory Committee members serve 4-year terms, with the possibility of a 6-month extension after the term expires until a successor is appointed. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members can be removed at the Secretary's discretion. The Chairperson is appointed for a 1-year term from among the members, who serve without pay. The Advisory Committee members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. Meetings are held at least twice annually and are open to the public with prior notice published. The Advisory Committee members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Advisory Committee shall advise the Secretary of the Treasury on theme or design proposals for coinage and medals, and recommend events, persons, or places to be commemorated through coin issuance. Seven members constitute a quorum for meetings. The Advisory Committee recommends issuing commemorative coins for 5 years after designation, specifying mintage levels and designs. Expenses are paid from the Mint Public Enterprise Fund. The Mint Director provides administrative support as needed. The Advisory Committee provides administrative support, technical services, and advice as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. They consult with the Commission of Fine Arts and submit an annual report to specified committees by September 30 each year. The Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee provides support and advice to the Secretary of the Treasury, consulting with the Commission of Fine Arts. The Committee submits an annual report to specified committees by September 30 each year. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Committee, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee is abolished. The Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee is abolished, and members may continue to serve on the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Technical and conforming amendments are made to relevant sections of the United States Code. Section 5134(c) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by removing paragraph (4) and redesignating paragraph (5) as paragraph (4). Title II clarifies existing law. Title II clarifies existing law regarding the payment of surcharges on numismatic items, ensuring that all costs are recovered before funds are paid to designated recipient organizations. The organization has raised funds from private sources equal to or greater than the surcharge proceeds from the sale of numismatic items. Unpaid amounts from surcharges imposed on numismatic items may remain unpaid to designated recipient organizations due to a matching fund requirement. Unpaid surcharge amounts from numismatic items will be deposited in the Treasury if not paid to designated recipient organizations. The amendment applies retroactively to the date of Public Law 104-208.
